results.title: Discovering psychology
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: A challenging series of programs on human psychology hosted by veteran psychology professor, Philip Zimbardo of Stanford University. New developments are measured against historical breakthroughs and theories are tested by the recent findings of leading researchers.

results.title: The Dolphin's gift
results.creator_credit: Kim Kindersley, Victoria Zr. Cotton and Zari Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by John Hurt, this beautifully photographed program introduces Fungi, a bottle-nosed dolphin who lives at the mouth of Dingle Harbour, County Kerry in south west Ireland. Fungi has been charming local people and visitors to County Kerry for six years, though why he came to the harbour is a mystery to locals and experts alike. We are introduced to local inhabitants who share their thoughts and feelings about Fungi and the precarious nature of the survival of dolphin’s around the globe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kim Kindersley, Victoria Zr. Cotton and Zari Productions

results.title: In space, toward peace
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 24 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
How can psychology aid astronauts in space? How can psychology end conflict that leads to war? In this program, Philip Zimbardo shows how psychologists can help astronauts battle physical stress, mental stress, anxiety, boredom and depression. He also examines the psychology of peace - the study of the process of dehumanisation in the nuclear arms race and the art of conciliation in negotiating for peace.

results.title: The Dogs of war
results.creator_credit: John irvin, Larry Dewaay and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: This rivetting adaptation of Frederick Forsyth’s best-selling novel of the same name stars Christopher Walken and Tom Berenger as mercenary soldiers involved in the overthrow of a corrupt black African dictatorship. An intricate game ensues where double cross is the rule and the strike force they have organised find themselves caught between the shadowy international cartel who hired them and the dictator they are sworn to depose. The story focuses with chilling accuracy on the perilous lives of mercenaries, soldiers for hire, and the dirty battles they fight, often impervious to the morality of the assignment and its political integrity.

results.title: The Artist
results.creator_credit: Lee R. Bobker, Helen Kirstt Radin and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Renaissance”.
This outstanding production documents the Renaissance through a study of lives and works of the artists who gave meaning to creative expression. Discover the triumph and trials of Brunelleschi, Leonardo Da Vinci, Michelangelo and other masters. Review the movement of persons from craftsmen to artists and the challenge to unwarranted control by the guilds, the church and affluent patrons. Finally, examine the currency of these issues through interviews with contemporary artists.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lee R. Bobker, Helen Kirstt Radin and Barr Media Group

results.title: A World reborn
results.creator_credit: Bill Jersey and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Renaissance”.
Presents an excellent overview of history and contribution of the Renaissance. Traces the 300 years of this age from the early ideas of pioneers such as Petrach and Jan Hus, who sparked new ways of thinking, to innovators like Brunelleschi and Maciavelli, to the artistic, scientific and political revolutions of the High Renaissance, to the years when Europe finally accepted a vision of the world that was changed forever.

results.title: Renaissance
results.brief_description: Explores the Renaissance, a turbulent 300 year period that gave rise to ideas and issues that transformed European culture and have shaped the modern world. In six parts, this series looks at the Renaissance from the perspective of the archetypal figures of the age.

results.title: Cognitive processes
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
Why have people always been able to link different elements and ideas into coherent relationships? It is our thoughts, our cognitive processes, that give meaning to everything. In this program, Philip Zimbardo examines the work of cognitive psychologists who study how people take in information, store it, transmit it and manipulate it, that is, exploring how we think and solve problems.

results.title: Language development
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
How do we learn to speak? Are we born with some innate ability to speak or do we learn by imitating our parents? This program looks at the stages a young child goes through in learning to speak and the roles that nature and nurture play in the process. We look at how parents unconsciously adapt their normal speech patterns when speaking to very young children, at recent research into biological maturation of the brain and facial muscles, and at the social situations which also contribute to this unique ability of the human species to communicate through speech.
